comment.text: mount.cifs fails with this release (5.18.9-200 was working) with "mount error(22): Invalid argument"
See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2106087 for the CIFS issue
Default & performance tests pass (KVM)
Default & performance tests pass (KVM)

Works on Acer Aspire Intel® Core™ i7-3632QM CPU @ 2.20GHz Memory: 15.4 GiB of RAM Graphics Processor: Mesa DRI Intel® HD Graphics 4000. Passed all kernel regression tests. wi-fi: Qualcomm Atheros AR9485 Wireless Network Adapter vendor: Lite-On driver: ath9k v: kernel pcie: speed: 2.5 GT/s lanes: 1
working fine at KVM, tests passed.

Works for me: all using the Mate Desktop Environment.

sirius: desktop 16GB Intel i7-3770 CPU desktop (SSD + 5 hard drives in RAID-6)
real:10m12.580s  user:4m37.262s  sys:5m1.841s

sedna: laptop 8GB Intel i5-2520M CPU Lenovo T420 (SSD only)
real:9m35.367s  user:3m46.401s  sys:4m45.169s

mercury: laptop 32GB AMD Ryzen 7 5700U with Radeon 5500 Graphics (SSD only)
rea1:15m7.027s  user:7m0.249s sys:6m6.218s

*** I’m intensely curious as to the reason for why sedna seems to randomly fluctuate between short (normally under 11 minutes) & extremely long (100+ minutes) elapsed times for the performance test!
No smoke yet, SMB mounts working, regression tests passing.
This is working OK in a VM.  No drama so far, networking is... networking... no smoke.
works for me!
i7-9700K(UHD Graphics 630): kernel regression test passed. Works fine for daily use.

Works for me.. The enabled Default and Performance tests pass OK.

AMD 965, x86_64 Work Station (legacy BIOS) SSD's > RAID1. Plasma DE from Zawertun's COPR. nVidia GT1030 card using nVidia RPM's from RPMFusion (515.57)

Lenovo Lenovo ideapad 330-15IKB
Intel® Core™ i5-8250U × 8
Mesa Intel® UHD Graphics 620 (KBL GT2)

Detail:
Until the last version, when I closed the notebook lid and reopened the microphone it worked normally, now it doesn't work anymore
Since 5.17.7, the microphone didn't work, but when I closed the notebook and opened it, it worked again. From this version on, closing is no longer useful.

still the issue with the pendisplay input only working once and after getting the pen out of the sensors reach it doesnt work anymore , worked with 5.17 borked since 5.18. anything else works as expected
Huion kamvas 20 Pro
R2600 
16GB RAM
RX480

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2022-34918 kernel: heap overflow in nft_set_elem_init()

long_desc.thetext:
A heap buffer overflow vulnerability was identified within the netfilter subsystem which can be exploited to achieve privilege escalation to root. In order to trigger the issue it requires the ability to create user/net namespaces. The reason of the vulnerability is the type confusion bug in nft_set_elem_init, and it is different vulnerability than similar CVE-2022-32250.

Reference:

https://lore.kernel.org/netfilter-devel/cd9428b6-7ffb-dd22-d949-d86f4869f452@randorisec.fr/T/

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2104586]
So I guess they decided against the embargo...

In reply to comment #3:
> So I guess they decided against the embargo...

If patch already public for Upstream (and both description public), then embargo doesn't make sense. First description became public by mistake and then patch became public too.

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9

Via RHSA-2022:6592 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2022:6592

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9

Via RHSA-2022:6582 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2022:6582

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9

Via RHSA-2022:6610 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2022:6610

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2022-34918

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of fedora-all.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# low, medium, high, urgent (required)
severity=high

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=2104423,2104586

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new
